title: 107_s1654
content: The Act, known as the "National Junior College for Deaf and Blind at the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind Act," addresses the low college completion rates for deaf and blind students, high dropout rates in the first 2 years of college, shortage of trained professionals, and limited distance learning opportunities for individuals who are deaf or blind. Establishment of the National Junior College for Deaf and Blind under the Education of the Deaf Act of 1986 to address issues such as low college completion rates and limited distance learning opportunities for deaf and blind students. The National Junior College for Deaf and Blind was established to ease the transition from high school to college, increase college attendance and completion for deaf and blind individuals, provide distance learning and residential facilities for technical training, prepare for successful employment, and train professionals to serve the deaf and blind community. The Secretary aims to establish the National Junior College for Deaf and Blind at the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind within a year of the Act's enactment. The agreement with the institute will focus on maintaining exemplary postsecondary education programs for individuals who are deaf or blind. The agreement with the National Junior College for Deaf and Blind at the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind will address the specific educational, technological, and special support needs of students who are deaf or blind. It will ensure that federal funds are used appropriately, require annual reports on operations and national mission activities, emphasize innovative auditory and visual devices in facility design, and establish outreach and recruitment policies. The agreement with NJCDB includes outreach and recruitment policies to employ individuals with disabilities, a scholarship program for students, and an authorization of $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002. Additionally, if the Secretary enters into an agreement with AIDB under this section, certain provisions regarding NTID will apply to NJCDB and AIDB, with modifications for individuals who are deaf, hard of hearing, blind, or of low vision. The National Junior College for Deaf and Blind (NJCDB) is established at the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind (AIDB) under the Education of the Deaf Act of 1986. Definitions for AIDB and NJCDB are provided in the Act.
